Award.AwardTitle: CS 10K: Developing and Supporting Computer Science Teachers Via Strategic Partnering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Delaware proposes Partner4CS, a project to design and evaluate a comprehensive set of professional development opportunities for middle and high school computer science teachers. Delaware, like many other states, does not have teacher certification in computer science, CSTA chapters, or a defined educational path that would prepare computer science teachers. Partner4CS aims to circumvent these problems. The project brings an interdisciplinary team -- including university faculty and undergraduates from the computer science, math education, and educational research disciplines -- that has strong engineering outreach and evaluation credentials. The team will develop (1) a 3-track summer professional development institute bringing together G6-12 teachers and high school students for skills development, teaching pedagogy, and community building; (2) an online learning environment that provides teachers with instant access to pedagogical and curricular support and means to communicate regularly with other teachers and university faculty; (3) a new college service learning 1-credit course weekly alternating undergraduate service to teachers in the classroom with college classroom sessions for planning and reflection; and (4) quarterly Saturday morning teacher workshops for G6-12 teachers and students to continue the summer professional development throughout the academic year. Carefully mentored undergraduates will assist in these programs, in turn gaining from interdisciplinary collaboration, teaching and lesson planning, and the opportunity to experience first-hand the potential impact of their computing expertise in helping others. Their service may also contribute to an improvement in the participation of underrepresented students in computing at the both the college and at the high school levels. Partner4CS will build on the CS PIs' experience in partnering computer science undergraduates in service learning with middle school teachers and on the Education PIs' established partnerships with regional schools for education student teaching experiences. It will leverage both the university's math education major requirement of taking computer science, and the timing of the University of Delaware replacing its current CS0 course by CS Principles in Fall 2012.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objectives of this project were to support the CS10K efforts by preparing both teachers in grades 6-12 and students to become creators in computing. Our overarching goal was to  develop a strong community of university faculty, undergraduates and 6-12 school teachers in the state of Delaware for the purpose of increasing learning and sharing that would ultimately impact student learning. This project provided the following outcomes in teacher professional development, partnership building, and policy.

Supporting computer science (CS) teachers and students: Since 2012, this project has developed and implemented five one-week summer professional development (PD) institutes, reaching a total of 166 teachers representing 13 different school districts and over 36 schools.  The materials and agendas developed for the PD institutes include a Computer Science Principles teacher training track and two tracks for teachers integrating computer science into elementary or middle school or existing high school courses (e.g., math, science, social studies, business, and technology). Likert scale responses on pre/post PD surveys indicated that teachers improved in their understanding of CS content. In addition to learning new skills, participants learned a variety of pedagogical strategies for teaching CS modeled during the PD (e.g., pair programming, project based learning) and became more confident in their ability to deliver a CS curriculum. The PD has been key to significantly increasing the number of students in Delaware schools taking computer science.  In the 2016-2017 academic year, 32 high schools taught at least one CS course, and 21 of those high schools offered the 3-course CS pathway (Exploring Computer Science, Computer Science Principles, and Computer Science AP with Java programming).  A total of 2375 students in Delaware took a CS course in 2016-2017, while 1128 student took the CS Pathway.  

While the summer PD institutes provided opportunities for the development of knowledge, skills, and pedagogy in teaching computing, teachers need ongoing support throughout the academic year. To accomplish this goal, the project established a Field Experience university course, where undergraduates in CS and secondary education (math and science) directly support teachers in their classrooms. This course was offered every semester, 10 instantiations thus far. Throughout the duration of the project, this program reached 80 undergraduates supporting a total of 31 teachers and approximately 700 students in nearby Delaware elementary, middle and high schools.  Findings from pre/post course surveys, weekly reflective journals maintained by undergraduates, and course artifacts indicated that undergraduates became more confident in their CS skills and in their ability to communicate technical information to teachers and students. Middle school students working with undergraduate students in after-school programs exhibited significant gains in their CS content knowledge and attitudes towards CS. Regarding the Field Experience course, important lessons included: (1) combining computational, pedagogical and field related activities that help improve undergraduates’ technical knowledge while preparing them to work with teachers in the field; (2) pairing up undergraduates so that they can support each other in the field; (3) coordinating efforts with teachers is more efficient using direct communication between teachers and their assigned undergraduate team; and (4) debriefing after each field experience visit using a reflective blog journal to facilitate sharing among undergraduates followed by class discussion to address common challenges. 

 

 

Policy: Partner4CS contributed to the establishment of a Delaware Career and Technical Education (CTE) pathway in CS that consists of a sequence of three courses, including two NSF-supported curricula. Further, through articulation agreements, high school students who successfully complete CSP or CS AP with a score of 4 or above will receive college credit from Delaware Technical and Community College. As of October 2017, Delaware passed the House Bill 15, requiring all high schools to offer at least one CS course, the option to replace a math requirement by a CS course, and the requirement for CS standards in the state.  The Partner4CS project team is working with the state on the standards adoption.

Community Building and Partnerships:  Since 2012, Partner4CS has established strategic partnerships with 13 school districts, teachers in over 36 schools, policy makers, and STEM leaders at the state level. Partner4CS was successful in establishing the only Computer Science Teacher Association (CSTA) chapter in Delaware in 2015, which holds monthly meetings organized by teachers.   On March 23, 2017, Partner4CS and the Delaware Department of Education jointly hosted its first Summit for Computer Science Education at the University of Delaware campus in Newark, Delaware.  More than 75 participants convened, including state leaders and government officials interested in computer science education, industry and business partners, non-profit organizations interested in computer science education, district administrators, college counselors, school administrators, K-12 teachers, and higher education faculty interested in computer science education. Multiple partnerships have developed from this meeting.


Last Modified: 11/29/2017
Modified by: Lori L Pollock
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The primary objectives of this project were to support the CS10K efforts by preparing both teachers in grades 6-12 and students to become creators in computing. Our overarching goal was to develop a strong community of university faculty, undergraduates and 6-12 school teachers in the state of Delaware for the purpose of increasing learning and sharing that would ultimately impact student learning. This project provided the following outcomes in teacher professional development, partnership building, and policy. Supporting computer science (CS) teachers and students: Since 2012, this project has developed and implemented five one-week summer professional development (PD) institutes, reaching a total of 166 teachers representing 13 different school districts and over 36 schools. The materials and agendas developed for the PD institutes include a Computer Science Principles teacher training track and two tracks for teachers integrating computer science into elementary or middle school or existing high school courses (e.g., math, science, social studies, business, and technology). In the 2016-2017 academic year, 32 high schools taught at least one CS course, and 21 of those high schools offered the 3-course CS pathway (Exploring Computer Science, Computer Science Principles, and Computer Science AP with Java programming). A total of 2375 students in Delaware took a CS course in 2016-2017, while 1128 student took the CS Pathway. To accomplish this goal, the project established a Field Experience university course, where undergraduates in CS and secondary education (math and science) directly support teachers in their classrooms. Middle school students working with undergraduate students in after-school programs exhibited significant gains in their CS content knowledge and attitudes towards CS. Regarding the Field Experience course, important lessons included: (1) combining computational, pedagogical and field related activities that help improve undergraduates? technical knowledge while preparing them to work with teachers in the field; (2) pairing up undergraduates so that they can support each other in the field; (3) coordinating efforts with teachers is more efficient using direct communication between teachers and their assigned undergraduate team; and (4) debriefing after each field experience visit using a reflective blog journal to facilitate sharing among undergraduates followed by class discussion to address common challenges. Further, through articulation agreements, high school students who successfully complete CSP or CS AP with a score of 4 or above will receive college credit from Delaware Technical and Community College. As of October 2017, Delaware passed the House Bill 15, requiring all high schools to offer at least one CS course, the option to replace a math requirement by a CS course, and the requirement for CS standards in the state. The Partner4CS project team is working with the state on the standards adoption. Partner4CS was successful in establishing the only Computer Science Teacher Association (CSTA) chapter in Delaware in 2015, which holds monthly meetings organized by teachers. On March 23, 2017, Partner4CS and the Delaware Department of Education jointly hosted its first Summit for Computer Science Education at the University of Delaware campus in Newark, Delaware. More than 75 participants convened, including state leaders and government officials interested in computer science education, industry and business partners, non-profit organizations interested in computer science education, district administrators, college counselors, school administrators, K-12 teachers, and higher education faculty interested in computer science education. Multiple partnerships have developed from this meeting. Last Modified: 11/29/2017 Submitted by: Lori L Pollock
